A pivotal aspect in advancing ZrZnOx catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation lies in the modulation of Zr-O-Zn active sites, with ZnO facets emerging as potential modulators of site activity. Whereas the beneficial influence of non-polar ZnO facets on ZrZnOx catalysts has been scarcely documented. Our investigation reveals that ZrZnOx catalysts exposed non-polar ZnO facets (ZrZnO-n) exhibit superior methanol selectivity (74 %) compared to those with randomly exposed ZnO facets (ZrZnO-r, 35 %). Characterization results demonstrate that it is ascribed to the formation of highly active Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ sites on ZrZnO-n, which facilitate H2 adsorption and dissociation. In situ spectroscopic studies and DFT calculations further substantiate this finding, demonstrating enhanced intermediates formation and more efficient hydrogenation processes. This research underscores the significance of ZnO facet engineering in the purposeful creation of efficient ZrZnOx catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Specifically, synthesizing methanol (CH3OH) through CO2 hydrogenation is appealing because it can potentially serve as a fuel with high energy density [6–8]. Recently, metal oxide catalysts such as In2O3-based catalysts, ZnO−ZrO2 solid solution, GaZrOx, and CdZrOx have garnered extensive research attention due to their excellent stability and high selectivity at higher temperatures [9–11]. In particular, ZrZnOx catalyst has attracted considerable interest owing to its cost-effectiveness among metal oxide catalysts and its promising capability to be integrated with a solid acid catalyst (such as an oxide-zeolite catalyst) for gaining higher carbon products [12]. It is generally agreed that Zr-O-Zn sites are the primary active sites in the ZrZnOx catalyst. To promote the potential development of the ZrZnOx catalyst, researchers are committed to exploring the key factors that affect its active site. Tada et al. indicated that ZnO clusters formed at lower Zn content were more likely to generate Zr-O-Zn sites, which serve as active sites for catalyzing CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [13]. Monai et al. elucidated that the redox state and the extent of Zn dispersion, governed by the ZrO2 support phase, are pivotal factors influencing methanol formation. Compared to large-sized ZnO particles existing in the ZnO/ZrO-m catalyst, the sub-nanometer ZnO moieties on the ZnO/ZrO-t catalyst lead to form more ZnOx-ZrOy interfacial sites, which enhanced the production of methanol [14]. Meanwhile, our group found that the electronic state of Zn plays a pivotal role in determining the activity of the Zr-O-Zn site. Zn sites in an electron-rich state can boost the H2 adsorption and dissociation to produce more Zn-H-Zn species [15]. Several studies have also demonstrated that the nature of surface oxygen species in ZnZrOx catalysts is crucial for the properties of active sites. Lee et al. systematically tuned the preparation conditions to synthesize ZnZrOx catalysts with varying surface oxygen content. Their results revealed a positive correlation between catalytic activity and surface oxygen content, with catalysts rich in surface oxygen and high specific surface area exhibiting superior performance [16]. Similarly, Mao et al. prepared a series of ZnZrOx catalysts with different oxygen vacancy and lattice oxygen ratios using a solid-phase grinding method. Their experimental results showed a linear relationship between methanol selectivity and lattice oxygen concentration, highlighting the critical role of lattice oxygen in CO₂ hydrogenation [17]. These studies have demonstrated that the nanoscale and electronic characteristics of ZnO and the nature of surface oxygen species are among the key factors influencing the activity of Zr-O-Zn sites. However, most of the ZnO in previous work was irregular in shape, with randomly exposed facets. The effect of ZnO facets has been overlooked. Considering the anisotropic nature of ZnO, which leads to distinct atomic arrangements, chemical environments, and electronic configurations across different facets, the chemical properties and surface oxygen characteristics of ZnO can be significantly modulated. As a result, the properties of the Zr-O-Zn active sites are also likely influenced by the ZnO facets. The effect of ZnO facets is widely and extensively studied in ZnO-supported metal catalysts. Some researchers suggest that the exposure of polar ZnO facet contributes to enhanced catalytic performance. Liao et al. discovered that exposing the polar facet of plate-like ZnO exhibits a more pronounced synergistic effect with Cu compared to ZnO exposed random facets or non-polar facets, leading to enhanced selectivity toward methanol from CO2 hydrogenation [18]. Chen et al. demonstrated that the polar facets of ZnO are associated with the number of oxygen vacancies, thereby boosting the catalytic efficiency of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [19]. In theory, polar facets, characterized by the presence of alternating cationic and anionic layers, often exhibit strong surface dipoles and high surface energy [20]. These features can lead to the stabilization of unique coordination environments and the generation of reactive sites, such as undercoordinated metal cations or oxygen vacancies, which are highly active in catalytic processes like CO₂ adsorption and activation [18]. Several studies have indicated that the exposure of other ZnO facets may hold potential benefits. As proved by He et al., a ZnO catalyst exposed (110) facet exhibits the synergic effects of high charge separation efficiency and effective activation of CO2 [21]. Waclawik et al. demonstrated that the surface low-coordinated O atoms are more prone to being saturated by H atoms, resulting in the release of a greater number of OH free radicals on the (1011) facet of ZnO, which is responsible for a higher photoactivity [22]. Moreover, Zhang et al. revealed that Pd/r-ZnO with ZnO nanorods as support, which exposed non-polar (100) and (101) facets, exhibits a higher activity than Pd/p-ZnO (ZnO nanoplate exposing polar 002 facets) and Pd/c-ZnO (ZnO exposing random facets) in CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid (FA) [23]. The above research implied that the activity of active sites in ZnO-supported metal catalysts is closely relevant to the exposure of ZnO facets. The influence of polar ZnO facets on defect sites, such as oxygen vacancies, is well-documented. However, the role of non-polar ZnO facets in modulating active sites remains underexplored. Unlike polar facets, non-polar facets lack strong surface dipoles and typically exhibit lower surface energy along with more uniform electronic properties. These characteristics enable the formation of well-defined active sites with tailored electronic structures, which may offer unique advantages in catalytic processes [20]. Motivated by this gap in knowledge, our study focuses on non-polar ZnO facets to investigate their role in modulating the electronic properties of Zn-O-Zr interfaces and their impact on catalytic performance in CO₂ hydrogenation in ZrZnOx catalysts. In this work, we unlocked the potential of non-polar ZnO facets over ZrZnOx catalyst on the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. ZrZnOx catalyst exposing non-polar ZnO facets (noted as ZrZnO-n) exhibited a higher methanol selectivity than ZrZnOx catalyst with randomly exposed ZnO facets (noted as ZrZnO-r) (74 % vs. 35 %). Based on this finding, the influence of the exposure of non-polar ZnO facets on the active site and reaction mechanism over ZrZnOx catalysts was further investigated. Characterization results indicate that the exposure of non-polar ZnO facets on ZrZnO-n catalyst leads to form the higher active Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ sites and facilitates the H2 dissociation as well as the formation and conversion of intermediates. It provides a new insight into the effect of ZnO facets over ZrZnOx on CO2 conversion. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All the chemicals employed were of analytical purity and utilized directly without any additional purification steps. Zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), Zirconium nitrate (Zr(NO3)4·9H2O), Ethylenediamine (C2H4(NH2)2) were sourced from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Absolute ethyl alcohol (C2H5OH) were obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) were acquired from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Throughout the study, deionized water (DI water) was used exclusively. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of ZnO samples ZnO exposed non-polar facets were easily prepared via hydrothermal synthesis. It should be noted that we attempted to synthesize ZnO exposed non-polar facets using three different hydrothermal methods [24–26], which were defined as ZnO-n, ZnO-n', ZnO-n", aiming to eliminate any randomness associated with the preparation process. Subsequently, the ZnO-n sample was chosen as the primary subject of investigation in the results and discussion section. ZnO exposed random facets (denoted as ZnO-r) were synthesized by the coprecipitation method. All the preparation details will be described in Supplementary Information. 2.2.2 Preparation of ZrZnOx catalysts ZrZnOx catalysts were prepared using a straightforward impregnation technique with a nominal loading of 10 wt %. Dissolve 0.19 g Zirconium nitrate (Zr(NO3)4·9H2O) in 20 mL of deionized water and add 0.50 g of ZnO samples. Stir the mixture at room temperature for 2 h and stand it for 1 hour, then dry it at 60 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, calcine the ZrZnOx precursors at 350 °C for 2 h. 2.2.3 Preparation of Zr+ZnO catalysts The Zr+ZnO catalysts were prepared using a simple physical mixing method. A specific amount of powdered ZrO2 was mixed with ZnO samples (ZnO-n or ZnO-r) in an agate mortar and ground thoroughly to ensure homogeneity. The resulting mixture, in which ZrO2 accounts for 10 wt % of the total catalyst mass, was used as the Zr+ZnO catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray excitation Auger spectroscopy (XAES), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2-TPR, Raman spectroscopy (Raman), SEM-Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometry (SEM-EDS), In-situ DRIFTS were used in this work. The details will be described in Supplementary Information. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation A catalyst weighing 0.20 g and sized between 20∼40 mesh was loaded into a quartz tube, which was then positioned inside a stainless-steel tube for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The reactor was fed with a reactant mixture having an H2/CO2 ratio of 3:1 and pressurized to 4 MPa. Details of calculation methods for reactant conversion and product selectivity are provided in Supplementary Information. 2.5 Calculations All calculations in this study were performed utilizing the Dmol3 module within Materials Studio. Detailed descriptions of calculation methods and models were provided in Supplementary Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The structure of ZnO exposed non-polar crystal facets (denoted as ZnO-n) and ZnO exposed random facets (denoted as ZnO-r) were investigated. XRD (X-ray diffraction) patterns of ZnO-n and ZnO-r shown in Fig. 1a correspond to the standard pattern of hexagonal wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS 89-0510). The 2θ diffraction peak intensities of ZnO-n at 31.8°, 34.4°, and 36.3°, which correspond to crystallized ZnO (100), (002), (101) facets, are stronger than that of ZnO-r, suggesting a superior degree of crystallization in the former. In addition, the peak intensity of (101) non-polar facet to (002) polar facet ratio (I(101)/I(002)) is calculated to reflect the exposure of ZnO crystal facets. As shown in Fig. 1b, the I(101)/I(002) ratio of ZnO-n (I(101)/I(002) = 1.93) is higher than that of ZnO-r (I(101)/I(002) = 1.71) [18,19], confirming that ZnO-n exposed more non-polar facets. TEM images in Figs. 2a and e, and S2a show that ZnO-n has a rod-like morphology with a lattice fringe of 0.246 nm, which is generally ascribed to the (101) non-polar facets. It is usually recognized that the ZnO rod-like structure is elongated along the [001] direction, with the (101) facets exposed on the sides [24]. Whereas ZnO-r exhibits irregular shapes with the lattice fringe of 0.257 nm and 0.240 nm, which respectively correspond to (002) and (101) facets (Figs. 2b and f), suggesting it grows randomly in multiple directions and results in a random exposure of crystal facets [27,28]. The above results prove that the ZnO-n surface is exposed to non-polar facets and the ZnO-r surface exhibits random crystal facets. Zr was added onto ZnO-n and ZnO-r separately by the impregnation method to form ZrZnOx catalysts (denoted as ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r, respectively). The SEM-EDX results suggest that Zr has been loaded onto the surface of ZnO successfully (Fig. S1). XRD pattern of ZnZrOx still correspond to the wurtzite ZnO structure except a slight reduction in peak intensity (Fig. 1a), and the I(101)/I(002) ratio shows little difference with pure ZnO (Fig. S3). Moreover, there are no diffraction peaks belonging to Zr phase observed in ZnZrOx XRD patterns, which means that the Zr phase exists in an amorphous form. TEM images show that the morphology of ZnO-n and ZnO-r remain unchanged after incorporating of Zr (Figs. 2c and d). The ZnO facets exposed on the surface of ZrZnOx also remain in the same state as before the Zr loading (Figs. 2g and h). These results of TEM, HRTEM and XRD imply that the addition of Zr has a negligible impact on the exposure of ZnO facets. ZrZnO-n sample features non-polar ZnO facets, while ZrZnO-r has randomly exposed ZnO facets. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of ZrZnOx catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 3a , the ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts exhibit similar CO2 conversion, while the methanol selectivity of ZrZnO-n (Sel.MeOH=74.8 %) is higher than ZrZnO-r (Sel.MeOH=35.2 %). To eliminate potential randomness of experiment, another two ZrZnOx catalysts using distinct preparation methods were synthesized, denoted as ZrZnO-n', ZrZnO-n" respectively, which also exposed non-polar ZnO crystal facets primarily (Figs. S4a and b). Distinctly, both ZrZnO-n' and ZrZnO-n" catalysts had similar catalytic performance with ZrZnO-n. These results suggest that ZrZnOx catalyst that exposed nonpolar ZnO crystal facets significantly improves the methanol selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation. To identify the active components in ZrZnOx catalyst, the following comparative experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 3b, ZnO-n shows a marginally higher methanol selectivity compared to ZnO-r (10 % higher), suggesting that the exposure of nonpolar facets have an effect on the nature of ZnO. However, the methanol selectivity of ZnO-n (31.8 %) and ZrO-r (22.4 %) remains low due to the absence of effective CO2 activation sites [11]. After adding Zr, the methanol selectivity of both ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts have improved than the corresponding pure ZnO and Zr/SiO2, indicating that the coexistence of Zn and Zr promotes to form methanol. Moreover, it is observed that the methanol selectivity of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts are also higher than that of the physically mixed catalysts Zr+ZnO-n and Zr+ZnO-r, respectively (Fig. 3c). Combined with previous literature reports, these are primarily ascribed to the formation of Zr-O-Zn bonds between Zr and Zn components in ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts, which has been generally regarded as the active site of ZrZnOx catalysts [11,13,29–31]. More importantly, ZrZnO-n exhibits a 39.6 % higher methanol selectivity compared to ZrZnO-r. The methanol selectivity of ZrZnO-n has also increased by 43 % compared to ZnO-n, significantly outpacing the 12.8 % increase observed in the comparison between ZrZnO-r and ZnO-r. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 3d, ZrZnO-n (87.4 ± 5.7kJ/mol) demonstrates a lower apparent activation energy than ZrZnO-r (122.4 ± 4.9kJ/mol). Therefore, we hypothesize that the ZrZnO-n catalyst may have formed Zr-O-Zn sites with unique properties compared to those in the ZrZnO-r catalyst, which is the crucial factor leading to its significantly enhanced methanol selectivity. 3.3 Effect on Zr-O-Zn active sites To probe the effect of exposing non-polar ZnO facets on the active sites of ZrZnOx catalyst, the following characterizations were conducted. Fig. 4a displays the Raman spectra of pure ZnO and ZrZnOx catalysts, allowing for detecting the changes in vibrational structures of metal-oxygen bonds. The modes at 101∼584cm-1 and 1154cm-1, which are present in both ZnO and ZrZnOx samples, are ascribed to the wurtzite structure of ZnO. In contrast to pure ZnO, two new peaks positioned at 735 cm⁻¹ and 1049 cm⁻¹ are observed in ZrZnOx catalysts. The 1049 cm-1 peak is found in the Raman spectra of ZrO2 (Fig. S5a), indicating it should corresponded to the Zr-O bond. While the 735 cm-1 peak does not belong to either ZnO or ZrO2 (Figs. S5a and b). Mechanically mixed Zr+ZnO catalysts depicted in Fig. S6 also exhibit no peak at 735 cm-1. As shown in Fig. S7, a slight shift of (100), (002) and (101) diffraction peaks of ZnZrOx were observed in contrast to the pure ZnO, which demonstrated that Zr is integrated into the ZnO lattice to form a ZnZr solid solution structure [12]. Therefore, the 735 cm⁻¹ peak is conclusively attributed to the Zr-O-Zn bond vibration formed by Zr incorporation into ZnO. These results clearly confirm that the Zr-O-Zn sites are formed in ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts. Temperature-programmed reduction in H2 (H2-TPR) demonstrates the interaction of Zr-O-Zn sites in ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 4b, the reduction profiles of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r can be divided into two regions, one of which emerges between 450 °C to 600 °C, and the other falls within the range of 600 °C to 800 °C. For bare ZnO-r and ZnO-n, a broad reduction peak spans the temperature range from 600 to 800 °C. However, no distinct reduction peaks were observed for Zr/SiO2 within the temperature range of 0∼900 °C, which is consistent with the well-known fact that ZrO2 is inherently difficult to reduce. Based on this observation, the reduction peaks of ZrZnOx catalysts can be attributed as follows: the peaks in the range of 600∼800 °C correspond to the reduction of pure ZnO, while the peaks between 450∼600 °C are associated with the reduction of Zr-O-Zn sites formed in the ZrZnOx catalysts [11,32]. Notably, the reduction temperature of Zr-O-Zn sites in ZrZnO-n (516 °C) is higher than that in ZrZnO-r (500 °C), indicating stronger interactions between Zr-O and Zn-O sites in the ZrZnO-n catalyst [33,34]. Typically, such interactions are accompanied by changes in the electronic properties of the active sites [15,35,36]. We propose that this electronic modulation is a key factor contributing to the enhanced methanol selectivity observed in ZrZnO-n. To validate this hypothesis, the electronic properties of Zr-O-Zn sites in ZrZnOx catalysts were further investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and DFT calculations. All peak locations have been standardized based on the C 1s peak positioned at 284.6 eV. The Zr 3d5/2 orbital of both ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r displays a peak at 181.8 eV (Fig. 4c) [37], with similar electronic properties of Zr sites. Conversely, different electronic properties of Zn sites between two catalysts are observed. As shown in Fig. 4d, all samples exhibit one main peak and a small peak assigned to Zn2+ and Zn(2−δ)+ (0 < δ < 2) species, respectively [15]. Crucially, the Zn LMM Auger peak of ZrZnO-n shifts to higher kinetic energy compared to ZnO-n (from 988.7 to 989.0 eV), while ZrZnO-r remains unchanged at 989.0 eV than ZnO-r. Integration of the Zn(2−δ)+ peak area reveals that ZrZnO-n has a higher proportion of Zn(2−δ)+ species (40.44 %) than ZrZnO-r (28.31 %) (Fig. S8). It confirms the change in the electronic properties of Zn-O sites on the ZrZnO-n catalyst, with low-valent Zn(2−δ)+-O sites becoming predominant. Additionally, DFT calculations further showed the different charge states at the Zn site between ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts. The optimized structures of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r models are shown in Fig. S9a and b, respectively. Fig. 4e presents the computed Mulliken charges of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r models, which provide qualitative insights into the electron density distribution at the Zn and Zr sites. It is observed that the Mulliken charge of Zr in ZrZnO-n (1.98) and ZrZnO-r (2.00) models shows minimal variation, indicating that the electronic environment of Zr site is relatively unaffected by the ZnO facet. In contrast, the Zn charge in ZrZnO-r (0.78, shown in Fig. 4eⅠ) is close to that of ZnO-r before Zr doping (0.77, shown in Fig. S10). However, a notable decrease in the Zn charge is observed for ZrZnO-n, from 0.78 to 0.36 after Zr doping (Figs. 4eⅡ and S11), which suggested that an electron-rich state Zn site (Zn(2−δ)+) is formed on ZrZnO-n catalyst. It is important to note that Mulliken charges are qualitative indicators of electron density distribution and should not be interpreted as precise measures of charge transfer [38]. Nevertheless, the observed trends align with the experimental findings and support the proposed role of ZnO faceting in modulating the electronic state of active sites. These results reveal that the Zn sites in Zr doping ZnO with randomly exposed crystal facets (ZrZnO-r) primarily exist as Zn2+, forming Zr-O-Zn2+ active sites. In contrast, the stronger interaction between non-polar ZnO facets and Zr facilitates the formation of Zn(2−δ)+ sites, which further leads to create Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+sites. Evaluation of catalytic performance demonstrates that the ZrZnO-n catalyst exhibits higher methanol selectivity than ZrZnO-r (Fig. 3). Consequently, it indicates that Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ active sites are more effective in promoting methanol formation than Zr-O-Zn2+ active sites. Several studies have demonstrated that the oxygen vacancies (OVs) in ZnZrOx catalysts are critical factors contributing to their catalytic activity in CO₂ hydrogenation [16,17]. To investigate whether non-polar ZnO facets influence the OV concentrations in ZrZnO catalysts, we quantified the OV concentrations before and after Zr doping using XPS O 1s spectra (Fig. S12). The results demonstrate that the modification of ZnO facets does not significantly affect the OV concentration, regardless of whether Zr is doped or not. It indicates that the observed changes in methanol selectivity, induced by the modification of non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnOx, are not caused by variations in OV concentration. In summary, the exposure of non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnO-n catalyst enhances the generation of Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ active sites, which are responsible for high methanol selectivity. 3.4 Effect on reaction mechanisms The above results underscore the pivotal significance of exposing non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnO-n catalyst for attaining higher methanol selectivity and Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ active sites, yet the underlying connection to mechanisms still requires in-depth exploration. Based on the evaluation result (Fig. 3a), ZrZnO-r and ZrZnO-n catalysts show similar CO2 conversion but significantly differ in methanol selectivity, suggesting that the exposure of non-polar ZnO facet over ZrZnOx catalyst may have an impact on the formation and transformation of key intermediates. During the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, H2 activation plays a crucial role in the consecutive hydrogenation of CO2 to formate intermediates and finally to methanol [10,39]. Kinetic experiments are presented in Fig. S13, which determine the apparent reaction order through adjustments to the partial pressures of CO2 and H2, all conducted under conditions of minimal CO2 conversion. The formation rate of CH3OH is accelerated with the increase of H2 partial pressure, but suppressed in excess of CO2 for both ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts. It indicates that the dissociation and activation of H2 has a positive effect on promoting methanol formation. ZrZnO-n catalyst (1.99) gives a lower H2 reaction order than ZrZnO-r catalyst (2.60), suggesting an easier process for the H2 dissociation and activation [15,33]. H2-TPD results further prove that the ZrZnO-n sample had a stronger H2 adsorption capacity compared to ZrZnO-r sample. It can be observed that both catalysts exhibit three H2 adsorption peaks within the temperature range of 150∼550 °C in Figs. 5a and S14, which correspond to weak, medium, and strong H2 adsorption peaks, respectively. Notably, the amount of H2 adsorbed on weak, medium, and strong adsorption sites for ZrZnO-n are all greater than that on ZrZnO-r sample (Fig. 5b and Table S1). Furthermore, ample evidence suggests that the Zn-O site serves as the catalytic site for activating H2 in ZrZnOx catalysts, and the active hydrogen species, such as Zn-H-Zn species, are formed at Zn-O sites during H2 dissociation, which are crucial for catalytic hydrogenation reactions [40,41]. In-situ DRIFTS spectra were recorded during 0.1 MPa and 10 % H2/Ar at various temperatures to demonstrate the relationship between ZnO with exposed non-polar facets over ZrZnO-n catalyst and hydride species. Figs. 5c and d show the In-situ DRIFTS spectra of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts in the 4000∼1000 cm−1 range. Both catalysts display two vibration bands of OH species at 3650cm-1 and bridging hydride Zn-H-Zn species at 1500 cm-1, underscoring the H2 heterolytic dissociation has occurred on their surfaces [15,42]. It is evident that the peak intensity corresponding to Zn-H-Zn species on both ZrZnO-r and ZrZnO-n catalysts gradually increase with rising temperature. However, a stronger peak intensity of Zn-H-Zn species is exhibited on ZrZnO-n than ZrZnO-r catalyst at elevated temperatures, indicating that the Zn(2−δ)+-O sites presented on the surface of ZrZnO-n catalyst are more conducive to dissociate H2 into Zn-H-Zn species than Zn2+-O sites over ZrZnO-r catalyst. To delve deeper into the molecular level understanding, DFT calculations were utilized to assess the energy required for the H2 activation pathway on both ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r models. The models of H2 activation process are described in Figs. S15 and S16. As shown in Fig. 6a , the transition state (TS) for both ZrZnO-r and ZrZnO-n catalysts represent the highest energy points, demonstrating that the activation energy from H2* (adsorption path) to TS is the decisive factor in the entire process [43]. Obviously, the energy barrier is much lower in ZrZnO-n model (0.46 eV, 44.1 kJ/mol) than in ZrZnO-r model (1.23 eV, 118.5kJ/mol) (Fig. 6a, Table S2). The H2 adsorption energies of two models also follow the same trend (−0.18 eV vs. −0.08 eV) (Fig. S17 and Table S2). Fig. 6b further shows that ZrZnO-n model with a higher Zn(2-δ)+ / (Zn2+ + Zn(2-δ)+) ratio corresponds to lower H2 adsorption energy and energy of barrier. The above results demonstrate that exposing non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnO-n catalyst facilitates better H2 adsorption and dissociation, leading to form more Zn-H-Zn species. These are ultimately attributed to the formation of Zn(2-δ)+-O sites in Zr-O- Zn(2-δ)+structure. For the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol over ZrZnOx catalysts, formate (HCOO*) forms on the Zr-O-Zn site from adsorbed CO2 and dissociated H, then hydrogenates to methoxy (CH3O), leading to methanol [44]. Therefore, the adsorption and dissociation ability of H2 are likely to influence the formation and conversion of key intermediates. In-situ DRIFTS spectra at 320 °C with H2/CO2 ratio of 3/1 showed in Fig. 7 is employed to investigate the variations in the key intermediates. Upon introducing the H2/CO2 flow, distinct vibration bands corresponding to HCOO* species (at 1367, 1379, 1592, 2872, 2973 cm-1) and CH3O* species (at 1054, 2827, 2944 cm-1) [9,45] are observed in both ZrZnO-n (Figs. 7a and c) and ZrZnO-r catalysts (Figs. 7b and d), with peak intensities increasing over time. For clear understanding, the characteristic peaks of HCOO* at 2872 cm-1 and CH3O* at 2944*cm-1 are normalized by peak intensity to represent the variation of the two main intermediates. As shown in Fig. 7e, it is clear that the ZrZnO-n catalyst exhibits a stronger peak intensity of both HCOO* and CH3O* species than ZrZnO-r catalyst during 30 min. The CH3O*/HCOO* ratio is also calculated to reflect the process of HCOO* hydrogenation into CH3O* in Fig. 7f. Notably, a higher CH3O*/HCOO* ratio is shown on ZrZnO-n compared to the ZrZnO-r sample. According to the DRIFTS results, the schematic diagram of catalytic mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation on the surface of ZrZnO-n and ZrZnO-r catalysts is showed in Scheme 1 . It is indicated that the enhanced H2 adsorption capacity and the increase of Zn-H-Zn species in ZrZnO-n catalyst not only favor the form HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates but also promotes HCOO* hydrogenation into CH3O*, which should account for the high Methanol selectivity. 4 Conclusion In summary, the effect of non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnOx catalyst on CO2 hydrogenation to methanol has been studied in detail. XRD and TEM demonstrate that the ZrZnOx catalysts with exposed non-polar ZnO facets (ZrZnO-n) and randomly exposed ZnO facets (ZrZnO-r) are synthesized successfully. Notably, the catalytic evaluation results show that ZrZnO-n catalyst exhibits an exceptional methanol selectivity than ZrZnO-r catalyst, suggesting that exposing non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnO-n catalyst plays a crucial role in enhancing the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. Multiple characterization results have proven that the exposure of non-polar ZnO facets in ZrZnO-n catalyst enhances the interaction between Zr and Zn sites, leading to form Zr-O-Zn(2-δ)+ sites, which are more active in catalyzing CO2 hydrogenation to methanol than Zr-O-Zn2+ sites over ZrZnO-r catalyst. In situ DRIFTS spectroscopy results reveal that such active sites in ZrZnO-n catalyst are more conducive to the H2 adsorption and dissociation, which further facilitate the formation of HCOO* and CH3O* intermediates, as well as the process of HCOO* hydrogenation into CH3O*. This work provides a novel understanding of ZnO facet effects over ZrZnOx on CO2 hydrogenation, which is also beneficial to foster the development of efficient ZrZnOx catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A pivotal aspect in advancing ZrZnOx catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation lies in the modulation of Zr-O-Zn active sites, with ZnO facets emerging as potential modulators of site activity. Whereas the beneficial influence of non-polar ZnO facets on ZrZnOx catalysts has been scarcely documented. Our investigation reveals that ZrZnOx catalysts exposed non-polar ZnO facets (ZrZnO-n) exhibit superior methanol selectivity (74 %) compared to those with randomly exposed ZnO facets (ZrZnO-r, 35 %). Characterization results demonstrate that it is ascribed to the formation of highly active Zr-O-Zn(2−δ)+ sites on ZrZnO-n, which facilitate H2 adsorption and dissociation. In situ spectroscopic studies and DFT calculations further substantiate this finding, demonstrating enhanced intermediates formation and more efficient hydrogenation processes. This research underscores the significance of ZnO facet engineering in the purposeful creation of efficient ZrZnOx catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation.
